ms.ipp.iterable.tree

Class AbstractTree<F>

  • java.lang.Object
    • ms.ipp.iterable.tree.AbstractTree<F>
  • Type Parameters:
    F - as in Tree.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.String,F>>, BiIterable<java.lang.String,F>, Tree<F>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DelegatingTree, StdMultiTree, StdTree, SyntheticTree

    public abstract class AbstractTree<F>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Tree<F>
    A basic abstract implementation of all features shared by the concrete sub-implementations. In particular, the following is implemented:
  • recursive methods, such as get(..), delete(..), peek(..), set(..);
  • some preliminary checks for doDelete(..), doPeek(..), doSet(..);
  • metadata setters, such as setRecursion(Recursion), setPathManipulator(PathManipulator), setUpdater(Class, BiConsumer), and the corresponding getters.
Author:
mykhailo.saienko

    • Method Detail

      • setUpdater

        public <T extends F> void setUpdater(java.lang.Class<T> key,
                                     java.util.function.BiConsumer<T,T> updater)
        Description copied from interface: Tree
        Sets an updater for a given type. If set(..) or doSet(..) are called and there is an updater for the passed type, it is called immediately before a new value replaces the old one. In this case, the old value is passed as the first and the new value - as the second parameter. WARNING: The updater assumes that the old value is of the same type as the new value. If this cannot be ensured, the affected set and doSet methods exhibit undefined behaviour.
        Specified by:
        setUpdater in interface Tree<F>
        Parameters:
        key - the type for which a given updater must be called
        updater - a new updater or null in order to remove the updater

      • peek

        public final <T> T peek(java.lang.String name,
                        java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
        Description copied from interface: Tree
        Retrieves a member with a given path and which is of a given type. If the path is not simple, the search is carried recursively. If there is no such member, returns null.
        Specified by:
        peek in interface Tree<F>
        Returns:

      • delete

        public final void delete(java.lang.String name,
                         java.lang.Object value)
        Description copied from interface: Tree
        The results depend on the content of the parameter value:
      • If value is not null, recursively deletes all elements with a given path which are equal to a given value.
      • If the value is null and the path identifies the element, this element is deleted.
      • Otherwise, the result is undefined.
Specified by:
delete in interface Tree<F>

  • doDelete

    public final void doDelete(java.lang.String name,
                           java.lang.Object value)
    Description copied from interface: Tree
    The results depend on the content of the parameter value:
  • If value is not null, deletes all children with a given name which are equal to a given value.
  • If the value is null and the path identifies the child, it is deleted.
  • Otherwise, the result is undefined.
    Specified by:
    doDelete in interface Tree<F>

  • set

    public final <T> T set(java.lang.String name,
                       T value,
                       java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
    Description copied from interface: Tree
    Sets a member with a given path to a given value. If the path is not simple, the search is carried recursively. If the member with the path cannot be found, reset or added, null is returned.
    Specified by:
    set in interface Tree<F>
    value - a new value to set for a given path. Must not be null.
    Returns:

    Specified by:

  • getBaseClass

    public java.lang.Class<F> getBaseClass()
    Description copied from interface: Tree
    Returns the Class-object of the template-parameter F. This is mostly used to check for compatibility of an input object at run-time.
    Specified by:
